sentence: However, as you wrote, I do think of Peter as a kind of brother…a younger brother; we’ve been sending out feelers, and a brotherly and sisterly affection may or may not develop at some later date, but it’s certainly not reached that stage yet.
I read a bit, daydreamed some more, looked at the clock and waited, waited, waited, all the while listening to his footsteps.

Oh, when I think back to Saturday night, to our words, our voices, I feel satisfied with myself for the very first time; what I mean is, I’d still say the same and wouldn’t want to change a thing, the way I usually do.
He came downstairs to tell Dussel it was time to listen to the radio and hung around the bathroom for a while, but when Dussel took too long, he went back upstairs.
After your letter of yesterday I have the unpleasant feeling that your conscience bothers you whenever you go to Peter’s to work or talk; there’s really no reason for that.
I think what surprised him most about me was when he discovered that I’m not at all the superficial, worldly Anne I appear to be, but a dreamer, like he is, with just as many troubles!
But I’m certain of one thing: if Peter and I do become friends, I’m going to tell him you’re also very fond of him and are prepared to help him if he needs you.
When he said I always helped him when his parents were arguing, I was tremendously happy; it was one step toward making me believe in his friendship.
His answer was: “If they were all like you, it wouldn’t be so bad.” He’s extremely hospitable, and I think he really likes to see me.
My answer: I think the best thing is simply to wait and see what happens.
All those jokes about marrying Peter if we stayed here long enough weren’t so silly after all.
The entire evening I was so restless I kept going to the bathroom to splash cold water on my face.
Last night after the dinner dishes, I waited for him to ask me to stay upstairs.
It can’t be much longer before Peter and I will have to decide whether to go back to the way we were or do something else.
I asked him yesterday what he’d do if there were a dozen Annes who kept popping in to see him.
In my heart, I know there’s someone who deserves my trust (as I do his), and I wouldn’t be able to tolerate Peter in his place.
Meanwhile, he’s been working hard at learning French, even studying in bed until ten-fifteen.
He paced up and down his room and went to bed early.
You wouldn’t want me to, I’m sure, but I don’t care; I don’t know what Peter thinks of you, but I’ll ask him when the time comes.
I think, Kitty, that true love may be developing in the Annex.
I went to bed early, exhausted.
You won’t be disturbing us, because we have an unspoken agreement to talk only in the evenings when it’s dark.
I can’t figure out if he wants only a good friend, or if he’s attracted to me as a girl or as a sister.
I don’t know how it’ll turn out; I can’t see any farther than the end of my nose.
Your time may come sooner than you think.
I’m sure now that Peter loves me too; I just don’t know in what way.
You’re welcome to join us in the attic, or wherever we are.
He’s so handsome, whether he’s smiling or just sitting still.
It’s certainly nothing bad—on the contrary!
Not that I’m thinking of marrying him, mind you.
Now that you’ve found companionship, enjoy it as much as you can.
Or if we’ll even love each other enough to get married.
But nothing happened; I went away.
I don’t even know what he’ll be like when he grows up.
Tonight I have to take a bath, and tomorrow?
Tomorrow’s so far away!
I’m doing my best, though it’s not always easy.
So there’s no need for you to feel sorry for me.
In the meantime, things are getting more and more wonderful here.
He’s so sweet and good and beautiful.
Keep your spirits up!
